item.title: The best â€“ but not good â€“ way to limit string length
item.description:
â€œHow long is this string?â€ should be the easiest question in software development, followed by: â€œHow do I limit the length of this string?â€ You can â€“ and should â€“ look up your programming language documentation for the former; for the latter, the answer takes of the form of: â€œThe easy choice isnâ€™t great, and the best choice is only marginally better.â€

Weâ€™re going to dive hard into these questions and try to fully grok what weâ€™re doing and why.

A TL;DR misses the â€œfully grokâ€ part, but not everyone has time to read everything, so here are the takeaways:

  1. Be aware that there are different ways of measuring string length.
  2. Really understand how your programming language stores strings in memory, exposes them to you, and determines string length.
  3. Make an intentional decision about how youâ€™re going to count characters when limiting string length.
  4. Make sure you use that same counting method across all the layers of your architecture.
  5. Look carefully at how the â€œmax lengthâ€ features provided by your language (framework, etc.) actually work. Thereâ€™s a very good chance that they do not match the limiting method you chose.
  6. Probably limit by counting normalized Unicode code points. (Like Google recommends.)

With that out of the way, letâ€™s start our investigation by looking at some of our familiar string length functions:

â€œaâ€ â€œå­—â€ â€œðŸ”¤â€ â€œðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ‘§â€ðŸ‘¦â€ â€œà¤°à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªâ€ â€œxÌ´ÍÌ‘ÍÍƒÍ™Ì¹Ì¬â€
Go len(string) 1 3 4 25 15 17
JavaScript String.length 1 1 2 11 5 9
Python 3 len(str) 1 1 1 7 5 9
Swift String.count 1 1 1 1 1 1

Those four measurements of string length are exemplars of the approaches common to most programming languages: UTF-8 bytes, UTF-16 code units, Unicode code points, grapheme clusters.

## Character encodings and terminology

There are good explanations of this stuff elsewhere, but letâ€™s try to quickly get a handle on the concepts we need to go further. (Feel free to skip anything youâ€™re already comfortable with.)

First, a working definition of â€œcharacterâ€: This is the human conceptual ideal of the smallest building block of most written languages1: a letter, an emoji, an ideograph, a punctuation mark, a symbol, a grapheme. Later on weâ€™ll also think of these as â€œif a user types this, they expect a â€˜character countâ€™ to increase by 1â€. All of the examples in the above table probably look like â€œa characterâ€ to you. (Weâ€™re going to avoid using this term lightly, in favour of technical correctness, to avoid confusion. So Iâ€™m never going to say â€œUnicode characterâ€.)

### Unicode

Unicode is our attempt to list all possible characters, plus a whole lot more: control characters, non-printable characters, fragments that can be combined to form characters, and so much more.

Each entry in the Unicode space is called a â€œcode pointâ€ and is represented with a 32-bit unsigned integer, though the actual usable space is only 2Â²Â¹ (1.1 million possible values) and only about 150,000 of those values have been assigned. You might also see the term â€œUnicode scalar unitsâ€ â€“ these are basically the same as code points, but exclude the reserved â€œsurrogate pairâ€ range.

Examples (character: code, decimal)

  • â€œaâ€: U+0061, 97
  • â€œå­—â€: U+5B57, 23383
  • â€œðŸ”¤â€: U+1F524, 128292

Strictly speaking, a â€œUnicode code pointâ€ is an abstract concept, with a numerical value assigned to each character. There are 3 common concrete schemes for encoding those code points: UTF-8, UTF-16, and UTF-32. â€œUTF-32â€ is a direct representation: 32 bits to encode the 32 bits, with endian variants. Iâ€™m going to prefer just saying â€œUnicode code pointâ€ for clarity. Weâ€™ll discuss UTF-8 and UTF-16 at length below.

Note that in Go, a Unicode code point is typically called a â€œruneâ€. (Go seems to have introduced the term for the sake of brevity. I certainly appreciate that, but Iâ€™m going to stick with universal terms here.)

### Grapheme cluster

Some Unicode code points can be combined and rendered into a single visual character; we call this a grapheme cluster. Sometimes this combined character has its own dedicated code point and doesnâ€™t need to be encoded as a multi-code-point grapheme cluster, but sometimes such a character can only be formed that way.

Weâ€™ll go through some examples, but note that they can get complex.

  • â€œðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ‘§â€ðŸ‘¦â€: composed of 7 code points
    1. â€œðŸ‘¨â€: U+1F468, â€œmanâ€
    2. zero-width joiner: U+200D, HTML entity ‍
    3. â€œðŸ‘©â€: U+1F469, â€œwomanâ€
    4. zero-width joiner: U+200D, HTML entity ‍
    5. â€œðŸ‘§â€: U+1F467, â€œgirlâ€
    6. zero-width joiner: U+200D, HTML entity ‍
    7. â€œðŸ‘¦â€: U+1F466, â€œboyâ€

The family emoji is an example of a â€œzero-width joiner (ZWJ) sequenceâ€.

Not all possible combinations of emoji (or code points generally) can be combined in such a way to create a single grapheme cluster character; whether and how itâ€™s rendered depends on the platform youâ€™re viewing it on. (And how itâ€™s rendered can change over time. In 2014, with Windows 10, Microsoft introduced the â€œninjacatâ€ ZWJ sequence emoji, combining the â€œcatâ€ and â€œninjaâ€ emoji. It wasnâ€™t supported by any other platform. In 2021, Microsoft removed support for it and now it renders as two separate emoji.)

There are also â€œcombining marksâ€ that are accents or other fragments that donâ€™t require a ZWJ between the code points.

  • â€œeÌâ€: composed of 2 code points
    1. ordinary letter â€œeâ€
    2. â€œÌâ€: U+0301, â€œCombining Acute Accentâ€

This is an example of a grapheme cluster that can instead be represented with a single code point: U+00E9 is â€œLatin Small Letter E With Acuteâ€ and is visually identical to the above, decomposed cluster. (See â€œUnicode normalizationâ€, below.)

Use of characters formed by grapheme clusters (that canâ€™t be normalized away) are extremely uncommon in languages that use European and and East Asian scripts, but fairly common in South Asian scripts, like Hindi where ~25% of characters involve a combining mark.

  • â€œà¤°à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªâ€: composed of 5 code points
    1. â€œà¤°â€: U+0930, â€œDevanagari Letter Raâ€
    2. â€œà¥â€: U+094D, â€œDevanagari Sign Viramaâ€
    3. â€œà¤¸â€: U+0938, â€œDevanagari Letter Saâ€
    4. â€œà¥â€: U+094D, â€œDevanagari Sign Viramaâ€
    5. â€œà¤ªâ€: U+092A, â€œDevanagari Letter Paâ€

  • â€œxÌ´ÍÌ‘ÍÍƒÍ™Ì¹Ì¬â€: composed of 9 code points
    1. ordinary letter â€œxâ€
    2. â€œÌ´â€, U+0334, â€œCombining Tilde Overlayâ€
    3. â€œÍâ€, U+035D, â€œCombining Double Breveâ€
    4. â€œÌ‘â€, U+0311, â€œCombining Inverted Breveâ€
    5. â€œÍâ€, U+035D, â€œCombining Double Breveâ€ (again)
    6. â€œÍƒâ€, U+0343, â€œCombining Greek Koronisâ€
    7. â€œÍ™â€, U+0359, â€œCombining Asterisk Belowâ€
    8. â€œÌ¹â€, U+0339, â€œCombining Right Half Ring Belowâ€
    9. â€œÌ¬â€, U+032C, â€œCombining Caron Belowâ€

As far as I can tell, there is no limit on the number of code points that can contribute to a single grapheme cluster â€œcharacterâ€. Weâ€™ll certainly keep that in mind when we think about how to limit string length, below.

(You will sometimes see the word â€œsegmentationâ€ used when talking about extracting grapheme clusters from a string. It generically refers to breaking a string into defined pieces; for example, the JavaScript Intl.Segmenter API can break a string into graphemes, words, or sentences.)

### Unicode normalization

Unicode normalization has two functional axes: composition/decomposition and compatibility simplification, resulting in four modes with standard names. The â€œNFâ€ is â€œnormalization formâ€; â€œCâ€ is â€œcanonical compositionâ€, â€œDâ€ is â€œcanonical decompositionâ€; â€œKâ€ is â€œcompatibility simplificationâ€. Which gives us:

No Simplification Simplification
Composition NFC NFKC
Decomposition NFD NFKD

Composition canonicalization will combine the two-code-point grapheme cluster form of â€œeÌâ€ (U+0065 + U+0301) into the single-code-point form â€œÃ©â€ (U+00E9); and similar for other grapheme clusters for which an equivalent single code point exists (and does nothing when there is no single code point; e.g., mostly doesnâ€™t change Zalgo text). Decomposition canonicalization will do the opposite: single-code-point characters will be decomposed into multi-code-point grapheme clusters where and equivalent exists (this includes decomposing Korean Hangul into jamo phonetic components).

Compatibility simplification converts some fancy characters into more ordinary ones. For example, â€œâ„â€ (U+210D) and â€œâ„Œâ€ (U+210C) become plain Latin â€œHâ€; superscript â€œÂ²â€ becomes plain â€œ2â€. The non-simplifying forms donâ€™t replace such characters.

NFC is good for keeping a string as compact as possible while ensuring greater consistency.

NFKC is good if you want the string to be searchable or otherwise comparable using equivalent characters (like matching â€œâ„ð”¼ð•ƒð•ƒð•†â€ when searching for â€œHELLOâ€).

I have trouble seeing when the decomposition canonicalization forms would be desirable (at least in a length-limiting context).

Note that accurate normalization is specific to each version of Unicode (of which there have been 16). For example, if the client has version N of Unicode, which added a new combining mark (accent) and normalization rules for composing it to a single code point, but then the client sends the unnormalized version of the string to the server running Unicode version N-1, then the server wonâ€™t be able to compose the grapheme the way the client expects.

### UTF-8

UTF-8 encodes code points into a sequence of 1, 2, 3, or 4 one-byte code units. It has the very nice property of providing a nicely compact encoding for most string data; in particular, all ASCII printable characters fit in one byte, with the same ASCII numeric value (e.g., if you open an ASCII view of a UTF-8 encoded source file, you can probably read it just fine). It is by far the most common encoding to find serialized to disk or on the wire (in recent years).

Note that there is overhead in the design2, so you donâ€™t get the full number of bits to represent code points. Hereâ€™s how it breaks down:

  • 1 byte: 7 bits
  • 2 bytes: 11 bits
  • 3 bytes: 16 bits
  • 4 bytes: 21 bits

### UTF-16

UTF-16 doesnâ€™t often get used on the wire or on disk, but it is used in-memory a lot. The reason is that some platforms and languages originally supported UCS-2, which is an old 2-byte Unicode standard. When Unicode increased to 4 bytes, UTF-16 was created. It uses 1 or 2 two-byte code units in a code point sequence. The first code unit is identical to and backwards compatible with UCS-2, making the transition for UCS-2 platforms reasonably easy.

(Two UTF-16 code units making a code point is often called a surrogate pair. There is also a â€œsurrogate pairâ€ reserved area in the UCS-2 spec that is used to indicate when a second UTF-16 code unit is used in the code point sequence.)

UTF-16 has the nice property that the entire â€œBasic Multilingual Plane (BMP)â€ fits in a single UTF-16 code unit. Thatâ€™s the â€œmajority of the common characters used in the major languages of the worldâ€ (but doesnâ€™t include emoji, notably). The downside is that it takes twice as much space to represent ASCII characters.

(Note that it takes three UTF-8 bytes to fit the entire BMP.)

### Other encodings

Weâ€™re not going to get into code pages, WTF-8, CESU, etc. Theyâ€™re not relevant to the task at hand (and I donâ€™t know enough to say anything useful).

## String lengths

Now that we understand character encoding better, letâ€™s revisit the table above.

Encoding Count â€œaâ€ â€œå­—â€ â€œðŸ”¤â€ â€œðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ‘§â€ðŸ‘¦â€ â€œà¤°à¥à¤¸à¥à¤ªâ€ â€œxÌ´ÍÌ‘ÍÍƒÍ™Ì¹Ì¬â€
UTF-8 code units 1 3 4 25 15 17
UTF-16 code units 1 1 2 11 5 9
Unicode code points 1 1 1 7 5 9
Grapheme clusters 1 1 1 1 1 1

So, different programming languages (and functions within a language) give us different methods of counting. Some examples3:

  • UTF-8: Go, Rust, C++â€™s std::u8string, Haskellâ€™s Text v2
  • UTF-16: Java/Android, JavaScript (and TypeScript), C#/.NET (and Windows), Objective-C/iOS (NSString), Haskellâ€™s Text v1.
  • Unicode: Python 3, Elixir, Ruby, PostgreSQL, Haskellâ€™s Char
  • Grapheme cluster: Swiftâ€™s String.count (but it also provides easy access to other encoding lengths), Elixirâ€™s String.length, Perl 6

Note that many (probably all) languages provide ways of converting between encodings and counting â€œlengthâ€ in those other encodings; the above are just defaults. There might also be a difference between which encoding is used in-memory versus which is presented as the main programming interface to access those strings.

To understand how our programming languages of choice deal with string length, itâ€™s worth taking a step back and thinking about what a string is. The definition of â€œstringâ€ that many of us would give is something like â€œa bunch of charactersâ€. But weâ€™ve seen now that â€œcharacterâ€ only has an abstract meaning, so itâ€™s not enough to help us when we use a string type. We need to know and keep in mind two things:

  1. the underlying in-memory representation of strings, and
  2. the view into that representation presented to us.

A few examples:

Goâ€™s string type is really an array of bytes. The intention is that those bytes hold UTF-8 code units, but thereâ€™s no guarantee of UTF-8 sequence validity. len(string) gives the byte length (and so the UTF-8 code unit count) of the string. Go provides unicode/utf8.RuneCountInString to get the Unicode code point count. It also has a unicode/utf16 package for converting between runes (code points) and UTF-16 code units. It has no built-in support for grapheme cluster segmentation.

JavaScriptâ€™s string type is a set of UTF-16 code units and string.length gives you a count of those code units. [...string] gives an array of Unicode code points. TextEncoder converts to UTF-8. Intl.Segmenter provides access to grapheme clusters.

Swiftâ€™s underlying representation used to be UTF-16 but has been UTF-8 since 2019. Its Character type holds a single grapheme cluster and String.count returns grapheme cluster count. To access encodings, it provides String.UTF8View, String.UTF16View, and String.UnicodeScalarView.4

Having a deeper understanding of how strings work under the hood will help prevent the confusion of discovering that a single emoji has a length of 7, and the bugs that can follow from that confusion.

### Limiting and Consistency

We finally get to the real point of this post!

Because there are 4 different ways to encode characters, there are 4 different ways to count string length. Because there are 4 different ways to count string length, there are (at least) 4 different ways to limit the length of a string.

That makes it really easy to be inconsistent across levels of your architecture, leading to bugs and bad user experience. They can be easy to miss in testing, since certain characters and character combinations might be needed to reveal them.

Here are a few length limiters that I was looking at when I decided I needed to write this post:

  • Go validator package (not stdlib, but popular): The max and min limiters count Unicode code points (â€œrunesâ€ in Go-speak).
  • If you create a column constraint with PostgreSQLâ€™s char_length(), itâ€™ll limit by Unicode code points (with default config).
  • The HTML attribute maxlength on input or textarea elements limits by UTF-16 code units. (Exceptâ€¦ I have found that in IE it limits by Unicode code points instead.)
  • React Nativeâ€™s TextInput.maxLength limits by UTF-16 code units. This is because on iOS it uses NSString.length and on Android it uses InputFilter.LengthFilter.

Rant: Itâ€™s really annoying that the method of counting length often isnâ€™t immediately apparent in the documentation. I should not have had to dig into React Native source code to get the answer. (And this isnâ€™t just an RN problem.)

Inconsistencies can arise between frontend clients and backend API servers, between API and database, between different client implementations, between different servers accessing the same database, and so on. Letâ€™s look at some problems that inconsistent length-limiting can lead to.

If the frontend allows longer input than the backend (perhaps by the frontend counting Unicode code points while the backend counts UTF-8 or UTF-16 code units), the frontend may indicate that the userâ€™s input is valid just to have it rejected by the backend.

If the frontend allows only shorter input than the backend, the user will be unnecessarily restricted. In the case of something like a username, if the account was created in a frontend with consistent counting and then the tries to login on a client with too-short counting, they might be unable to. One can imagine other too-long data might cause a frontend to freak out: assertion failure, refuse to display it, force the user to change it, etc.

Similar problems will occur with length-restrictions at other levels, such as between backend(s) and database.

Be intentional and consistent with how you limit string length. Donâ€™t just blindly use the default on whatever OS you happen to be on and whatever language you happen to be programming in.

Problem severity reality check: Probably allowing this kind of inconsistency wonâ€™t result in a fatal bug. Probably it wonâ€™t render your UI unusable or crash your server. Probably it wonâ€™t introduce an ugly security vulnerability (unless you try to count by grapheme clusters; see below). Most users arenâ€™t going to create usernames that are maximum length. Most users wonâ€™t use characters beyond the BMP in their username (although expect emoji elsewhere). You could probably go your whole career not paying any attention to this and probably not get bitten hard by it. But a) youâ€™re curious, and b) you want to limit the margins on â€œmostâ€ and â€œprobablyâ€, so letâ€™s figure out how to do this better.

### How to limit?

This is the question that really prompted me to write this post: Whatâ€™s the best way to limit string length input?

Letâ€™s go through each encoding type again and consider them as candidates for limiting. Weâ€™ll be thinking about it from both UI and API points of view. Keep in mind that the way youâ€™re â€œlimitingâ€ is often different on the frontend versus backend: on the backend, youâ€™re probably just rejecting the input (HTTP 400); on the frontend, youâ€™re either a) showing the user theyâ€™ve typed beyond the limit and telling them to fix it, or b) preventing them typing beyond the limit, or c) truncating the input.

Letâ€™s also make explicit: Usually, the reason we want to limit count is because we want to limit size. We donâ€™t want infinitely long usernames, chat messages, or even books. Even if we had no trouble displaying them, we donâ€™t want to process and store them. Limiting by count rather than byte-size can be more humane, and weâ€™ll keep this in mind as we consider approaches.

#### Grapheme clusters

Because theyâ€™re closest to representing what humans think of as a â€œcharacterâ€, grapheme clusters seem like they should be the right thing to count. But theyâ€™re actually the worst because, again, thereâ€™s no limit on the number of code points in a grapheme cluster. Maybe you can use them to limit count, but you canâ€™t use them to limit size. (At maximum â€œcrazinessâ€, zalgo.org adorns the letter â€œxâ€ with 360 accents and whatnot â€“ for 361 total code points. Swiftâ€™s String.count still, correctly, says thatâ€™s one grapheme cluster.)

(Perhaps you could limit the number of code points per cluster, but youâ€™d be breaking the Unicode spec and itâ€™s probably a bad idea. For something along those lines, see the â€œHybrid Countingâ€ section below.)

Grapheme clusters also require additional processing and interpretation. This is more of a rendering problem (e.g., iPhones have had multiple crash bugs), but a complex code path during input validation (potentially before authentication, etc.) should give anyone pause. (But Iâ€™m about to recommend Unicode normalization during validation, which is basically the same thing. Also, converting between any encodings requires some kind of â€œinterpretationâ€, but with varying complexity.)

More than the other options, operating at the grapheme cluster level is sensitive to differences between Unicode versions. For example, if a new grapheme cluster is added, a newer segmentation algorithm will count it as 1, while an older Unicode version may count it as the individual code points.

Not all programming languages have built-in grapheme cluster segmentation support. For example, Go has third-party packages, but no support in the stdlib or in golang.org/x/text.

#### UTF-16 code units

If youâ€™re starting from the frontend, thereâ€™s a good chance that UTF-16 will be your default choice. There are reasons why itâ€™s not a good choice.

A danger in length-limiting by counting code units is that you inadvertently break a character by truncating some of code units in a sequence. React Nativeâ€™s iOS limiter suffered this for at least 5 years before fixing it. It looks like RNâ€™s Android limiter avoids this (â€œIf a surrogate pair is encountered at the boundary, it backs off by one character to avoid splitting the pairâ€).

Counting by anything except grapheme clusters means that your count can jump by more than one per â€œcharacterâ€, which is not the worst thing ever, but obviously undesirable UX. There are two reasons for this jump-counting:

  1. Applies to Unicode code points, UTF-8, UTF-16: If the character is a multi-code-point grapheme cluster.
  2. Applies to UTF-8, UTF-16: Multiple code units are required to encode the code point.

The first reason can be somewhat mitigated by using NFC normalization with every keystroke â€“ to the extent possible, that will reduce clusters down to single code points. (Introducing latency while typing is also bad UX! Make sure to test the timing and feel.) We discuss this point more in the Unicode section below.

The second reason canâ€™t be mitigated for UTF-8 and UTF-16 â€“ by design, they can require multiple code units per code point. However, itâ€™s much less of a problem for UTF-16, since the whole Basic Multilingual Plane fits in one code unit, though it depends on the type of input expected â€“ itâ€™ll still be a two-count per emoji, at least.

Iâ€™m going to reiterate the caveat to that last point: the vast majority of commonly used characters are located in the BMP, and therefore fit in one UTF-16 code unit. Therefore, for the vast majority of commonly used characters, counting by UTF-16 code units is equivalent to counting by Unicode code points. The big exception to this is emoji.

Another big factor is that, while UTF-16 is quite commonly used in-memory, itâ€™s very unusual for it to be serialized on the wire or to disk (UTF-8 is used most commonly, rarely UTF-32). Because â€œsize on wireâ€ and â€œsize on diskâ€ are things we care about when limiting, it feels strange to count by the one format that we know wonâ€™t be serialized. But letâ€™s not overstate it: UTF-16 will still get us within about a factor of two of serialized size.

Using UTF-16 maximizes the amount of encoding conversion weâ€™re going to have to do.

Additionally, in programming languages that primarily use UTF-8 or Unicode code points, UTF-16 seems to be a second-class. For example, in Go, strings are UTF-8 and runes are what you get when you iterate over a string, but UTF-16 support requires the unicode/utf16 package. PostgreSQL doesnâ€™t seem to support UTF-16 at all.

#### UTF-8

UTF-8 is a tempting choice because a) itâ€™s a simple byte count, and b) itâ€™s likely what weâ€™re serializing to on the wire and on disk. Itâ€™s also very space-efficient for English text, although less so for other languages.

Counting characters by UTF-8 bytes in the UI is doomed to be confusing. For anything but plain English, the count will regularly increment by 1 or 2 or 3 or 4, and in ways that are not reasonable for a human to predict.

Itâ€™s important to note that there is a wide range in the significance of a string length limit to the UI/UX. On one end of the spectrum, there are very short fields with visible character counts; an obvious example is the old 140-character tweet limit, which users would stare at while trying to figure out creative contractions that wouldnâ€™t obscure their point too much. On the other end is, say, a 10,000-character message board limit, where itâ€™s not expected that many users will get near it; probably you donâ€™t even bother showing the count, and you just hard-limit the input.

When thereâ€™s a very high limit, added for sanity and safetyâ€™s sake, it doesnâ€™t really matter how you count characters. Youâ€™re not exposing the count to the user, and you probably donâ€™t care if the limit is 10,000 UTF-32 code points, 20,000 UTF-16 code units, or 40,000 UTF-8 bytes.

But when the count is low and exposed to the userâ€¦ UTF-8 counting is going to look weird.

#### Unicode code points

Argument from authority: Googleâ€™s API design guidance states that string size limits must be measured in Unicode code points, and that those strings should be NFC Unicode normalized.

I think this is approximately the best approach â€“ not just for APIs, but also for UIs â€“ but itâ€™s certainly not ideal. I would also upgrade the â€œshouldâ€ be normalized to â€œshould almost alwaysâ€.

Counting by Unicode/UTF-32 code points means that everything in the Basic Multilingual Plane and many emoji get a count of 1. Thatâ€™s an improvement over UTF-16 (and UTF-8). It also doesnâ€™t suffer from the interpretative counting of grapheme clusters.

Butâ€¦

It still suffers from many of the problems mentioned above:

  1. It can still count by more than one. Multi-code point grapheme clusters are not uncommon for some scripts (such as Devanagari, used by more than a billion people) and some emoji (such as all country flags).

  2. Input limiting by code point in a way that isnâ€™t grapheme cluster-aware might truncate characters â€“ causing them to be nonsense or otherwise confusingly incorrect. This isnâ€™t hypothetical! I found that React Native on Android (but not iOS) does exactly this.

    (The Canada flag emoji is a cluster made of a â€œRegional Indicator Symbol Letter Câ€ followed by a â€œRegional Indicator Symbol Letter Aâ€, but the length limit is truncating after the â€œCâ€.)

  3. Normalization is needed to limit grapheme clusters, and possibly per-keypress in the UI. Not a big deal, but extra complication and processing.

Even with those caveats, I think counting by Unicode code points is the sanest choice.

#### Hybrid counting

If we were inventing the best possible counting method, what would it look like?

Probably: Grapheme clusters without the unbounded risk.

We would want:

  • a count of 1 for each â€œcharacterâ€ â€“ even multi-code-point grapheme clusters in scripts like Devanagari
  • a count of 1 for each emoji â€“ even multi-code-point compounds
  • more than a count of 1 for technically-a-single-grapheme Zalgo explosions

I think it would be reasonable to do that with logic like:

  • For each grapheme cluster:
    • Are there N or fewer code points in the cluster? It counts as 1.
    • Otherwise, it counts as 1 plus the number of code points above N.

What should N be? (Following answer mostly based on this informative StackOverflow post.)

The longest well-defined grapheme cluster I have found is 10 code points ("ðŸ‘¨ðŸ»â€â¤ï¸â€ðŸ’‹â€ðŸ‘¨ðŸ¼" â€“ â€œKiss - Man: Medium-Light Skin Tone, Man: Medium-Light Skin Toneâ€). So maybe 10 should be our limit.

Unicode defines a Stream-Safe Text Format, which applies a limit of 30 (post NKFD nomalization). â€œThe value of 30 is chosen to be significantly beyond what is required for any linguistic or technical usage. While it would have been feasible to chose a smaller number, this value provides a very wide margin, yet is well within the buffer size limits of practical implementations.â€ So maybe 30 should be our limit.

(If I understand the Stream-Safe Text Process correctly, it provides a decomposition algorithm that is similar to what I suggested above. However, it would be more generous: a Zalgo character with 100 combining marks under my counting system would get a length of â€œ71â€ (if N=30); under the Stream-Safe Text Process, it would be broken into 4 pieces. Iâ€™m inclined to be less generous, but either approach still provides a bound, which is what we want.)

## Other considerations

There remain important questions and problems that are outside the scope of this post, but Iâ€™ll mention them here so you can keep them in mind.

### Unicode versions

Older Unicode text is compatible with newer Unicode versions, but the reverse is not necessarily true. For example, new versions may:

  • Add new emoji and other characters (code points)
  • Add new valid grapheme clusters, including multi-code-point emoji
  • Update grapheme cluster segmentation rules
  • Change character normalization rules

Possible problems that could be introduced include:

  • If counting by grapheme clusters, there could be a mismatch between frontend and backend, causing them to disagree about whether a string is valid.
  • Normalization could be different between frontend and backend, introducing the possibility of string length counting differences.
  • A valid emoji entered on one client may not be valid on other clients with older system Unicode versions.
  • If there are two different backends with different Unicode versions, they may not normalize a username the same way, resulting in one of them being unable to look it up. (Similarly for passwords. Or any other string matching.)
  • If strings are normalized and hashed (e.g., for signing or HMAC) in one place, and then the raw string is sent somewhere else for verification, the normalization may not produce the same string, resulting in a different hash. (So donâ€™t try to modify the input before checking. For example, the JSON Canonicalization Scheme specifies that â€œAlthough the Unicode standard offers the possibility of rearranging certain character sequences, referred to as â€œUnicode Normalizationâ€, JCS-compliant string processing does not take this into consideration. That is, all components involved in a scheme depending on JCS MUST preserve Unicode string data â€œas isâ€.â€)

And so on. (For a real-life story of this kind of version mismatch, search for â€œoperating system-provided ICUâ€ here. It also links to a scary discussion about Unicode version differences in glibc causing PostgreSQL index corruption when the same data is used on a different server machine. â€œNo surprise; I have been expecting to hear about such breakage, and am surprised we hear about it so rarely. We really have no way of testing for breakage either. :-(â€ Yikes.)

I have never seen â€œUnicode versionâ€ be specified as a requirement in an API (or other) spec, but I think it should be, strictly speaking. Otherwise you canâ€™t be certain that both sides understand strings in the same way.

On the other handâ€¦ This is probably another case of being overly paranoid. At this point in time, Unicode probably isnâ€™t changing things so drastically that major breakage is likely.

  • It seems grossly unlikely that anyone would be using a brand new grapheme cluster in a username.
  • A slight counting difference for a single character (which, while rare, would surely be a lot more likely than many such characters) will very rarely make the difference between â€œvalidâ€ and â€œtoo longâ€.
  • Most backends (I imagine) donâ€™t need to worry about character validity â€“ they just store the code points. Later theyâ€™ll send them back to the same client, which will interpret them the way they did before. Mostly. Probably.
  • We already accept that different OSes, browsers, and clients donâ€™t necessarily render characters or emoji the same way. (I was reminded of this the other day when I sent a coworker the character â€œðª˜€â€ for testing and was surprised when it didnâ€™t render for her. (Thatâ€™s a Chinese character beyond the BMP, in case it also doesnâ€™t render for you.))

Lots of â€œmostlyâ€, â€œrarelyâ€, â€œprobablyâ€, â€œunlikelyâ€ weasel words, but they multiply together to not really be worth the hassle. Probably.

### Normalization concerns

It might be tempting to have your API require that strings be Unicode normalized before submission, because: a) youâ€™re already normalizing on the frontend in order to count the length, and b) itâ€™s your API and you make the rules. But I think itâ€™s a bad idea.

First of all, youâ€™re not going to trust the API-caller to actually do it, so youâ€™ll have to do the normalization yourself anyway.

â€¦And then compare your normalized input with the raw input. But then see above for Unicode version concerns â€“ you could end up in a pathological state where the backend refuses to accept perfectly valid input.

### Encoding errors

Another thing to learn about your programming languages of choice is how they handle bad UTF-8 or UTF-16 encodings, and how youâ€™re going to handle that when it happens.

It seems common to replace broken sequences with the Unicode replacement character, U+FFFD. E.g., when Goâ€™s json.Unmarshal encounters a bad UTF-8 code unit sequence, it silently replaces it with U+FFFD.

Should you detect such characters? Treat them as bad input? Or just pass them through?

### Processing overhead

In many cases, accessing (or counting) character encodings other than the one used for natively storing your strings is an O(n) operation. That is, the string needs to be scanned through to answer questions like, â€œhow many UTF-16 code units are in this UTF-8 string?â€, â€œhow many Unicode/UTF-32 code points in this UTF-16 string?â€, â€œhow many grapheme clusters?â€ â€“ converting from the internal encoding to the target.

For most situations, with most string lengths, this isnâ€™t a significant performance problem, but keep it in mind if youâ€™re doing this inside a big loop, or with huge data, or in an HPC context.

Swift, for one, leaves â€œbreadcrumbsâ€ after the first conversion, to speed up subsequent non-UTF-8 string accesses. I donâ€™t know about other languages, but I donâ€™t think this is common.

## Conclusions

What prompted me to write this was when I realized that UTF-16 was the (unstated) encoding used for string length counting and limiting in a project I was reviewing. This felt wrong to me: variable number of code units; not first-class in some languages I cared about; kind of a weird in-between. When I tried to swoop in with some â€œsenior dev has seen it allâ€ shitâ€¦ I realized that I didnâ€™t have a solid suggestion with clear reasons. And thatâ€™s a good excuse to work them through in a blog post.

One surprising â€“ to me â€“ outcome of this research is that UTF-16 isnâ€™t actually a bad choice: for most languages, most of the time, only one code unit is needed for a non-emoji character. And itâ€™s not like using Unicode code points is a huge improvement: for most languages, most of the time, only one code point is needed, including for most emojiâ€¦ except, you know, for all those languages (spoken by a billion people) and emoji that make liberal use of grapheme clusters.

That being said, I think that counting by Unicode code points (with normalization) is the best approach. Did I take 6,000 words to say â€œjust do what Google suggestsâ€? /**
 * Counts the number of grapheme clusters in a string, with a sanity limit on the number

 * the remaining code points in the cluster are counted as one each.
 * The limit is intended to be larger than the number of code points in in legitimate

 * like Zalgo text.
 *
 * @param {string} s - the input string
 * @returns {number} - the grapheme length

function graphLength(s) {
 // A bit of research suggests that the locale arugment is ignored for grapheme segmentation
 const seg = new Intl.Segmenter(undefined, { granularity: 'grapheme' });

 // Iterate through the grapheme clusters
